TextBlock._LCLZText: Checks the active simulation study to ensure it has all data required to solve the given study type. The icon changes the color according to the study state:

The study cannot be solved because some important inputs are missing - for example, for static stress simulation, a load is not applied. For thermal study, a temperature load is missing. Or, for any study, there are incorrect material data.
There are some potential issues with the study, but it can still be solved. For example, the design is not fully constrained (not enough constraints), or contacts are missing.
The study has no predictable issues; therefore it can be solved.
Checks the active generative study to ensure the setup meets the requirements to generate outcomes. The icon changes color according to the study status.
You can't generate outcomes because the study setup doesn’t meet some requirements. For example, there is less than the minimum number of preserve geometries or a material is missing.

You can generate outcomes, but there are potential issues with the study. For example, a preserve, obstacle, or starting shape body is missing, but the study includes the minimum number of preserve geometries.
The study setup meets the requirements.
View the list of the Simulation solves related to all the open documents which are in progress or have already been done.
The available list allows you to track progress of the solve, cancel the solve in progress or view the results for the successfully finished solve.
Displays the list of generative jobs that are in progress or have completed for all open documents.
The list enables you to track processing status of each generative job and cancel the job in progress.
You can cancel a generative job before one iteration of any outcome is generated.
Check explicit solve.
Computes a mesh for your simulation model based on settings specified. Automatic contacts are generated first.
Your computer will be used to perform the compute process.
Use this command to generate and inspect the mesh prior to solving on the cloud, especially if you have customized the mesh settings.
Because the mesh is automatically created when you start solving on the cloud, this step is optional. In many cases, however, it is good to inspect the mesh and make adjustments before solving.
Note that you can monitor the mesh generation progress in the Simulation Job Manager.
Runs your simulations based on the settings you select. Progress bar displays to view the state of the solve. Automatic contacts and mesh are generated first.
Runs your simulations on cloud based on the settings you select.
Performs your simulations based on the specified settings. You are able to schedule to solve simulations on cloud or locally.
Automatic contacts and mesh are generated first. Progress bar displays to view the state of the solve.
Generates outcomes that satisfy the design requirements specified in the generative study.
You can select one or more studies in your design. Track the processing status in the Job Status dialog.
Runs your simulations based on the settings you select. Progress bar displays to view the state of the solve.
Runs your simulations based on the settings you select. Progress bar displays to view the state of the solve.
Automatically calculates the contact types between all bodies and components that overlap or touch each other.

To ensure all contacts are included in the simulation, run Automatic Contacts before assigning manual contacts. Note, you can then later change the contact types from the automatically generated one to the desired type. Also, you can suppress contacts to be excluded from the simulation.
Applies contact conditions to component geometries.
After you detect all automatic contacts, you can create additional contacts between components. The simulation type determines the availability of contact types.

Tips._LCLZText: Select the two bodies or components that participate in the contact first. This will isolate those two bodies. The command automatically toggles between the selected bodies when you click the geometric entities where the contact applies.

Select a new contact type.
For manual contacts, unselect the target geometries or bodies, and select new ones.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Bonded surfaces mean the two surfaces are in full contact.

All loads from a surface will be fully transferred to another surface in contact. This means that deflections and temperatures are identical where the parts meet, and heat flows without resistance between the adjacent parts.
Please note that before manually applying contacts, you should run Automatic Contacts.

Tips._LCLZText: Select the two bodies or components that participate in the contact first. This will isolate those two bodies. The command automatically toggles between the selected bodies when you click the geometric entities where the contact applies.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Contact surfaces can separate freely from each other in the normal direction and move freely relative to each other in the tangential direction.
Please note that before manually applying contacts, you should run Automatic Contacts.

Tips._LCLZText: Select the two bodies or components that participate in the contact first. This will isolate those two bodies. The command automatically toggles between the selected bodies when you click the geometric entities where the contact applies.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Contact surfaces can move freely away from each other (but not pass through each other) in the normal direction, and cannot move in the relative tangential direction once they come in contact.
Please note that before manually applying contacts, you should run Automatic Contacts.

Tips._LCLZText: Select the two bodies or components that participate in the contact first. This will isolate those two bodies. The command automatically toggles between the selected bodies when you click the geometric entities where the contact applies.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Contact surfaces can move freely in the relative tangential direction, but cannot move relative to each other in the normal direction.
Please note that before manually applying contacts, you should run Automatic Contacts.

Tips._LCLZText: Select the two bodies or components that participate in the contact first. This will isolate those two bodies. The command automatically toggles between the selected bodies when you click the geometric entities where the contact applies.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Offset Bonded Contact.
Please note that before manually applying contacts, you should run Automatic Contacts.

Tips._LCLZText: Select the two bodies or components that participate in the contact first. This will isolate those two bodies. The command automatically toggles between the selected bodies when you click the geometric entities where the contact applies.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Shows meshing issues on the model.
Meshing issues.
Hides meshing issues.
Meshing issues.
View the list of all contacts.
The list allows you to sort, edit, rename, suppress, and isolate contacts.
Shows resulting reaction forces and moments.

Tips._LCLZText: Select a constrained face, edge or vertex to see reaction values.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Refine the mesh in specific locations by modifying the mesh distribution on Faces and edges.

To improve results fidelity, strategically refine the mesh at certain locations. Refine the mesh in areas that have a large result gradient or have small geometric features that the global mesh size may not capture. Select Surfaces or edges, and drag the slider. Validate that the mesh is sufficient before running the simulation using the Generate Mesh command.

Tips._LCLZText: Select a surface or edge and drag the slider to modify the local mesh distribution. You can also manually enter the element length. The green dots provide an approximate nodal distribution on edges, but the final mesh may differ slightly due to neighboring features.

Description._LCLZText: To improve results fidelity, strategically refine the mesh at specific locations. Refine the mesh in areas that have a large result gradient or have small geometric features that the global mesh size may not capture. Select Surfaces or edges, and drag the slider. Validate that the mesh is sufficient before running the simulation using the Generate Mesh command.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Specify the optimization objectives and load case constraints.
Set the target mass, objectives, manufacturing constraints, and maximum allowed displacement.
Specifies the optimization objectives and limits that the outcomes should satisfy.
You can specify the Safety Factor for the objectives. For the Maximize Stiffness objective, you can also specify the Mass Target.

Tips._LCLZText: If you select Minimize Mass, enter a Safety Factor or accept the default value. If you select Maximize Stiffness, specify a Safety Factor and Mass Target.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Specifies the manufacturing constraints for the design process.
Available options include: Unrestricted, Additive, and Milling. You can select all options and compare outcomes generated for each option.

Tips._LCLZText: To include additive constraints, select Additive and specify the Overhang Angle and Minimum Thickness. To include milling constraints, select Milling and specify the Tool Direction, Minimum Tool Diameter, Tool Shoulder Length, and Head Diameter. To avoid manufacturing constraints during the design process, select Unrestricted.

Description._LCLZText: Outcomes are generated for each manufacturing option that you select.

TextBlock._LCLZText: Generates an outcome preview based on the study setup before you run a job.

Use Previewer to see how the setup affects outcomes. Then adjust the setup, if needed. Previewer ignores manufacturing and material settings. It generates the preview after Pre-check verifies that the study is ready to generate.
Toggles display of the Learning Panel where you can view the Generative Guide.
It walks you through the steps to set up a generative study. Each step is updated based on your model and study setup. After completing all steps you can generate outcomes.
Deletes elements from the mesh that, during the event simulation, fall into the region of emerging cracks, breaks, and holes.

Define the criteria that must be met for elements to be deleted. Select the target body, the deletion criterion, and the value. Only mesh elements of the selected body that meet the deletion criteria are deleted.

Tips._LCLZText: Provides options for deleting elements from the mesh based upon criteria defined.
Provides options for deleting elements from the mesh based upon criteria defined.
